doc_id=1322 igt_id=igt1322-67 1649 1663 M+LN+CN L G B M M M M M M M B M B T+AC
language: North Russian (rus)
line=1649 tag=M+LN+CN:  (37) North Russian: Long Form Predicative Participles
line=1650 tag=L:       a.
line=1651 tag=G:          whom:DAT key:NOM.MASC given:MASC.LF
line=1652 tag=B:
line=1653 tag=M:  33
line=1654 tag=M:    Most instances of long form participles used predicatively are MASC.SG (i.e., /-nyj/-tyj/), which may
line=1655 tag=M:  certainly be argued to have led to the isolation of /-n/-t/ (cf. (1b)). In fact,         (1972:217) notes that
line=1656 tag=M:  the use of predicative long form MASC.SG /-nyj/-tyj/ is most widespread precisely in the area where short
line=1657 tag=M:  form MASC.SG /-n/-t/ is the standard -no/-to allomorph. The extent to which this development affects
line=1658 tag=M:  /-no/-to/ itself is unclear from the printed sources and the reader is therefore warned that any conclusions
line=1659 tag=M:  here can only be tentative.
line=1660 tag=B:
line=1661 tag=M:                                                 32
line=1662 tag=B:
line=1663 tag=T+AC:              `To whom was given the key?' [K&N 1971:286]

line=221 tag=M+DB:     Russian verbal forms exist in simple and perfective
line=222 tag=T+DB:                                                                                             "Masha         was eating cake/Masha used to eat cake."

line=228 tag=G+DB+CR:                                                                                             Masha
line=229 tag=M+DB:  (e.g. s-jest tort "eat the cake") (Brecht, 1984; Paducheva,
line=230 tag=T+DB:                                                                                             "Masha         ate the cake."

line=270 tag=G+DB:           Masha eat-PAST piece      cake-GEN

line=273 tag=M+DB:                                                                               telicity, an inherent endpoint to the eventuality. It can be
line=274 tag=C+DB:           eat a piece of cake."

doc_id=2979 igt_id=igt2979-3 434 469 L G+LN M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M B B T+EX C
language: Russian (rus)
line=434 tag=L:  (7a) On               nadeetsja          na     nej.
line=435 tag=G+LN:  Rus 3sgNOM            rely.on.3sg        on     her-ACC
line=436 tag=M:
line=437 tag=M:
line=438 tag=M:  8
line=439 tag=M:    We use the terms `transitivity-conserving' and `transitivity-reducing' in a general sense to refer to the
line=440 tag=M:  situation in which original transitivity type is maintained (whether it be intransitive, transitive,
line=441 tag=M:  ditransitive), and the situation in which the original transitivity type is reduced, respectively. In this
line=442 tag=M:  section we focus particularly on reciprocal constructions formed from transitive clauses. We hold off
line=443 tag=M:  the discussion of reciprocal constructions and ditransitive clauses until §5.
line=444 tag=M:  9
line=445 tag=M:     In standard transitives it appears to be universal that it is the object that is replaced by the reciprocal
line=446 tag=M:  marker, never the subject; the commonest explanation given for this within the generative literature
line=447 tag=M:  derives this from the need for the antecedent to c-command the anaphor, though there are alternative
line=448 tag=M:  explanations in terms of thematic hierarchies. In some languages it is also possible for the reciprocating
line=449 tag=M:  arguments to be two non-subjects, e.g. `I introduced John and Mary to one another'; in which case the
line=450 tag=M:  reciprocal expression always replaces the oblique argument. It is generally the case that the possibility
line=451 tag=M:  of both arguments being non-subjects is limited to languages that do not encode the reciprocal relation
line=452 tag=M:  on the verb, but use free expressions.
line=453 tag=M:  10
line=454 tag=M:      English each other is odd, for a NP, in lacking any noun within it. Nonetheless, standard grammars
line=455 tag=M:  of English typically refer to it as a `reciprocal pronoun' (Huddleston & Pullum 2002:1499; Quirk &
line=456 tag=M:  Greenbaum 1973:105), though Jespersen (1933:112) implies some (undiscussed) doubt through his
line=457 tag=M:  formulation `so-called reciprocal pronoun'.
line=458 tag=M:  11
line=459 tag=M:      The Russian reciprocal examples are from Nedjalkov (1991); the non-reciprocal examples have been
line=460 tag=M:  constructed by us to illustrate the base structures.
line=461 tag=M:
line=462 tag=M:
line=463 tag=M:                                                        8
line=464 tag=M:
line=465 tag=M:  Compromising Transitivity: the Problem of Reciprocals
line=466 tag=B:
line=467 tag=B:
line=468 tag=T+EX:        'They rely on each other.' [verb subcategorizes for preposition na plus
line=469 tag=C:        accusative]

line=940 tag=B:
line=941 tag=B:
line=942 tag=B:
line=943 tag=M:            26
line=944 tag=M:               See Franks (1994) for further agreement differences between SC and Russian. Among other things,
line=945 tag=M:  Franks shows that in SC the sg option is possible even with collective verbs like gather, in contrast to Russian. This
line=946 tag=M:  leads him to treat agreement with SC and Russian numeral subjects differently, as discussed below.
line=947 tag=B:
line=948 tag=G:            going home five women(pl) is about that discussed(sg)

line=89 tag=M+AC+LN:  d.   Russian (Babby 1975)
line=90 tag=B:
line=91 tag=B:
line=92 tag=M:  3
line=93 tag=M:   The following abbreviated glosses are used: Acc: accusative case; AF: agent focus; Cau: causative;
line=94 tag=M:  Excl: exclusive; Fut: future; Gen: genitive case; Incl: inclusive; Lnk: linker; Loc: locative case; M:
line=95 tag=M:  Male; NAF: non-agent focus; Ncm: non-common noun marker; Neg: negation; Nom: nominative case;
line=96 tag=M:  Pfv: perfective; Pl: plural; Red: reduplication; Refl: reflexive marker; Sg: singular. The glosses of the
line=97 tag=M:  data taken out from other authors will stay as they are in the original sources.
line=98 tag=B:
line=99 tag=M:                                                      2
line=100 tag=B:
line=101 tag=M:                                                                                            3
line=102 tag=B:
line=103 tag=B:
line=104 tag=L:      on zastrelil-sja
line=105 tag=G:      he-NOM shot-REFL
line=106 tag=T:      `He shot himself.'
